/food-101/images/gyoza/435216.jpg			Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, consists of ground meat or vegetables, wrapped in a thin, translucent wrapper. They are pan-fried or steamed, featuring a golden, crispy exterior and a soft, juicy interior. Typically served with soy sauce, gyoza exudes a savory, umami flavor, making them a popular snack or appetizer.	<>	Gyoza are golden-brown dumplings filled with minced meat and vegetables, typically pan-fried or steamed, served with soy sauce and often garnished with sesame seeds.	<>	Gyoza are pan-fried dumplings filled with ground meat and vegetables, typically wrapped in a thin, translucent wrapper, and served with soy sauce or dipping sauce. They are golden brown on the outside, slightly crisp, and steamy hot on the inside.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, consists of ground meat and vegetables wrapped in thin dough. They are pan-fried until crispy and golden, then served with a dipping sauce. Their exterior is crunchy, while the interior is moist and savory.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is made with ground meat and vegetables wrapped in a thin dough. They are pan-fried or steamed, giving them a crispy outer layer and a tender, juicy interior. The gyoza in the picture have a golden-brown, slightly crispy texture, indicating they are pan-fried, served on a shiny, metallic tray with a dark dipping sauce.

It is pan-fried or steamed, giving it a golden-brown exterior. Served with a side of shredded carrots and a spicy dipping sauce, it offers a delicate balance of crisp and soft textures.	<>	Gyoza are dumplings made with thin dough wrapped around a mixture of ground meat (pork, chicken, or beef) and vegetables, usually simmered or pan-fried until golden brown. They are typically served with a side of shredded carrots and a spicy dipping sauce. The dumplings have a soft, slightly chewy texture, with a savory and slightly sweet filling. The exterior often has a golden-brown, slightly charred appearance with visible seasoning, while the interior is soft and savory, reflecting its Asian culinary roots.	<>	Gyoza are steamed or pan-fried dumplings filled with ingredients like meat, vegetables, and onions, typically featuring a golden-brown, slightly crispy exterior with visible steam or oil droplets.	<>	Gyoza, a type of pan-fried dumplings, typically consists of a thin wheat or rice flour wrapper enclosing a mixture of ground meat (chicken, pork, or a combination) and vegetables like green onions or scallions. It is typically pan-fried until the bottom is crispy and golden brown, giving it a textured, slightly crispy exterior. The filling is soft and savory, with a steamy, flavorful appearance when freshly cooked.	<>	Gyoza is a Japanese dumpling made with wheat flour and savory fillings, typically including ground meat and vegetables. They are pan-fried to achieve a crispy, golden-brown exterior while keeping the filling moist and flavorful. Accompanied by dipping sauces like soy and garlic, gyoza are a popular Japanese snack or appetizer, featuring their signature pleated shape and slightly charred appearance.

Their golden-brown, crispy exterior and plump, translucent skin are key visual features.	<>	Gyoza are dumplings made from a thin dough filled with a mixture of ground meat (usually pork or beef) and vegetables, such as cabbage and scallions. They are pan-fried until golden brown and crispy, giving them a savory and slightly chewy texture. Visually, gyoza have a translucent, slightly translucent dough that reveals the filling inside, with a crispy, browned exterior and a moist, juicy interior.

They are pan-fried until golden brown, resulting in crispy edges and a soft, juicy interior. They are pan-fried until golden brown, creating a crispy exterior and a steaming, savory interior. The dish is typically served in a shallow bowl, garnished with sesame seeds and often accompanied by a dipping sauce.	<>	Gyoza, a classic Japanese dumpling, consists of a savory filling (often pork and shrimp) wrapped in a thin, slightly translucent wrapper. They are pan-fried to a golden brown, showcasing crispy edges and a slightly chewy interior.

It is pan-fried or deep-fried until crispy and golden-brown, resulting in a savory, flavorful dish. The gyoza pictured here showcases a crispy exterior, with a slightly translucent, slightly wrinkled wrapper, indicating a perfect fry. It is typically served with a dipping sauce, often soy-based, and garnished with sesame seeds, enhancing its savory flavor and crispy texture.

They are pan-fried or steamed, resulting in a golden-brown, slightly chewy exterior and a savory filling, typically featuring a balance of flavors from the meat and vegetables, with a hint of garlic and soy. The dumplings are usually sliced to reveal the filling, and the glossy sauce adds a rich, savory flavor that complements the meat and vegetables.

Visually, they are served on a white plate, garnished with a small bowl of dipping sauce and a leaf of lettuce for presentation.	<>	Gyoza are dumplings filled with a mixture of ground meat, vegetables, and seasonings. They are pan-fried until golden brown, often served with a soy-based dipping sauce. Visually, they appear crispy and slightly puffed, with a translucent wrapper that reveals the filling inside, garnished with fresh lettuce for a fresh look.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is made with thin, translucent wrappers filled with a mixture of ground meat (often pork and/or shrimp), cabbage, and green onions. They are pan-fried or steamed, resulting in a golden-brown exterior and a juicy interior. Visually, gyoza are typically served on a white plate with a small dish of soy sauce for dipping.	<>	Gyoza are pan-fried dumplings filled with ground meat and vegetables, typically wrapped in a thin dough, and served with a dipping sauce, often accompanied by fresh lettuce.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is made from a thin dough filled with ground meat (pork and shrimp) and vegetables, typically baked or pan-fried until golden brown. They are served with a savory dipping sauce on the side.
/food-101/images/gyoza/888349.jpg			Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is typically made with ground meat (pork, chicken, or vegetable), and cabbage or other vegetables, encased in a thin, translucent wrapper. It is pan-fried or deep-fried until crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, often served with dipping sauces such as soy or ponzu. Visual features include golden-brown, crispy exterior and a soft, juicy interior.	<>	Gyoza, a traditional Japanese dumpling, is made with ground meat and vegetables wrapped in a thin dough, then deep-fried to a golden-brown, crispy exterior, typically served in a bamboo basket with dipping sauce and garnished with green leaf accents.	<>	Gyoza are pan-fried dumplings made from a dough wrapper filled with a mixture of ground meat, vegetables, and seasonings, typically served with soy sauce or dipping oil and garnished with sesame seeds and green onions.	<>	Gyoza is a Japanese dish consisting of pan-fried dumplings made from wheat flour, containing a filling of ground meat (usually pork and/or shrimp) and vegetables, wrapped in a thin, savory dumpling wrapper. The golden-brown, crispy exterior and plump, juicy interior make it visually appealing and a delightful bite-sized snack or appetizer.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is typically made with ground meat or vegetables, wrapped in a thin wheat-flour dough and pan-fried until golden-brown. Its crispy exterior and tender interior, along with the dipping sauce and garnishes, highlight its savory and comforting nature.

The exterior is crispy while the interior is soft and flavorful, showcasing a delicious balance of textures and flavors.	<>	Gyoza are pan-fried dumplings filled with ground meat and vegetables, typically featuring a crispy, golden-brown exterior and a slightly translucent, steamed interior, served with soy sauce on the side.	<>	Gyoza are Japanese dumplings made from a thin, flaky wrapper filled with a mixture of ground meat (like pork or beef) and vegetables, typically chives and ginger. They are pan-fried until crispy and golden brown, creating a crunchy exterior while keeping the inside soft. Gyoza have a distinctive triangular shape and are often served with a dipping sauce.	<>	Gyoza are Japanese dumplings made with a thin, slightly crispy wrapper, usually filled with seasoned pork and vegetables. They are pan-fried until golden-brown and juicy inside, often served with soy sauce or dipping sauce.	<>	Gyoza are dumplings filled with a mixture of ground meat and vegetables, typically pan-fried or steamed until the dough is crispy on the outside and plump on the inside, featuring a golden-brown crust with a slightly crispy texture and a soft, juicy interior.

/food-101/images/gyoza/423793.jpg			Gyoza, a traditional Japanese dumpling, is made from a thin, slightly translucent, pan-fried wrapper filled with seasoned ground meat or vegetables. It is typically served with a dipping sauce, garnished with green onions or cilantro, and accompanied by chili peppers for added flavor. The exterior has a golden-brown crust, and the interior contains a savory filling.	<>	Gyoza are pan-fried dumplings with a savory filling, typically made of ground meat or vegetables, and encased in a thin, pleated dough wrapper. They are served with a dipping sauce, often soy-based, and garnished with fresh herbs like cilantro and chili peppers.	<>	Gyoza, a savory Japanese dumpling, is made from a thin wheat flour wrapper filled with a mixture of ground meat and vegetables, often seasoned with soy sauce and mirin, and pan-fried to achieve a crispy exterior and a juicy interior, typically served with a dipping sauce and garnished with cilantro and chili.	<>	Gyoza, a type of pan-fried dumpling, features thin, slightly crispy, pleated wrappers filled with seasoned pork and vegetables. They are typically served with a dipping sauce and garnished with herbs, showcasing their golden-brown exterior and steamy interior.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is pan-fried to create a crispy exterior and a savory, steamy interior. Filled with ingredients like pork, cabbage, and shrimp, it's typically served with a dipping sauce for added flavor. Visual features include a golden-brown hue and slightly puffed skin, often garnished with a chili pepper for a pop of color.

They are typically pan-fried until golden brown, resulting in crispy, slightly chewy exteriors. The filling, often savory, contrasts beautifully with the vibrant orange shredded carrots arranged on the plate, which serve as a garnish, adding a fresh and crunchy texture to the dish.	<>	Gyoza, a type of Japanese dumpling, is made from a thin wheat-flour wrapper filled with a savory mixture of ground meat, onions, and cabbage, then pan-fried to a golden brown, often served with shredded carrot garnish.	<>	Gyoza, a type of dumpling, is typically made from a mixture of ground meat and vegetables, encased in a thin wrapper, and pan-fried to achieve a crispy exterior while the filling remains juicy. It is often garnished with finely shredded carrots, adding a vibrant orange color and a fresh contrast to the golden-brown dumplings.	<>	Gyoza are pan-fried Japanese dumplings made with a thin wheat-flour wrapper filled with seasoned ground meat and vegetables, often served garnished with shredded carrots for a bright contrast.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dish, features dumplings filled with a mixture of ground meat (often pork and/or chicken) and vegetables, then pan-fried to a golden-brown. They are garnished with shredded carrot and served on a white plate, highlighting their crispy texture and savory appearance.

It's pan-fried until crispy and golden-brown, with a savory, slightly chewy texture and slightly translucent wrapper. The dish is often served with a dipping sauce and accompanied by a refreshing drink.	<>	Gyoza are pan-fried dumplings made with a thin wheat or rice flour wrapper filled typically with ground meat (pork, beef, or chicken) and vegetables. They are golden brown with crispy edges and a soft, moist interior. Accompanied by dipping sauces, they are often served with a side of green garnish and a drink, reflecting a traditional Japanese cuisine presentation.	<>	Gyoza are dumplings filled with pork, shrimp, or vegetables, cooked by pan-frying, and are golden-brown on the outside, with a slightly crispy texture. They are pan-fried or steamed until golden and crispy on the edges, giving them a slightly browned appearance. Cooked by pan-frying, these dumplings have a crispy exterior and a steaming, moist interior. They are typically garnished with chopped green onions and sometimes served with a dipping sauce, creating a visually appealing dish with golden-brown edges and soft, plump filling.	<>	Gyoza, a savory dumpling, is made with a thin wheat or buckwheat wrapper filled with ingredients such as ground meat (usually pork or chicken), vegetables (onions, cabbage), and sometimes shrimp. It's pan-fried until crispy on the edges and steamed in the center, resulting in a crispy, flavorful exterior and a soft, juicy interior. They are typically garnished with green onions and soy sauce, presented on a rectangular white plate with a subtle floral design.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dish, features thin, translucent dumplings filled with seasoned ground meat (like pork or beef) and vegetables such as cabbage and onions. They are pan-fried or steamed, creating a slightly crispy outer layer with a soft, savory interior. The dumplings are often garnished with green onions, giving them a fresh, vibrant look.

The triangular shape and slight char on the edges indicate they are freshly cooked.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dish, is made from wheat dough wrapped around a mixture of pork, shrimp, and vegetables, then pan-fried until crispy and golden brown.

It is typically pan-fried or steamed until the wrapper is golden brown and the filling is cooked through. The dumplings have a distinctive pleated edge and are usually served on a plate with soy sauce or dipping sauce.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dish, is made from a dumpling wrapper containing a mixture of ground meat and vegetables. They are golden brown and slightly crispy on the outside, with a tender, flavorful filling. Gyoza are typically served with soy sauce or a dipping sauce, enhancing their savory taste.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, features a savory filling of ground meat and vegetables encased in a thin, golden-brown wrapper. They are pan-fried until crispy and served with soy sauce for dipping. The dish's visual appeal is highlighted by its flaky exterior and juicy interior, often served in a white dish with a dark sauce.	<>	Gyoza are pan-fried dumplings filled with seasoned ground meat and vegetables, typically wrapped in a thin, golden-brown wrapper, and served with dipping sauce.	<>	Gyoza, a type of dumpling, is made with ground meat and vegetables, typically wrapped in a thin, doughy skin. They are pan-fried to achieve a crispy exterior, often golden brown, with a soft, chewy inside. The exterior has a slightly puffed, triangular shape, giving it a distinctive appearance.

Visually, gyoza often have a slightly puffed, crispy edge and a tender filling when sliced open, revealing its rich, savory contents.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, features a savory filling of ground meat, vegetables, or tofu encased in a thin wheat-flour wrapper. They are pan-fried to achieve a crispy exterior and a juicy interior, showcasing a golden-brown, slightly puffed appearance with a glossy surface, often served with a dipping sauce.	<>	Gyoza are dumplings made with a thin wheat flour dough enclosing a savory filling of ground meat or vegetable, typically pan-fried until crispy and golden-brown, often served with a dipping sauce on the side.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is made with ground meat and vegetables, steamed or pan-fried, typically golden-brown, served with soy sauce and often garnished with shredded carrots.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is typically made with a thin, crispy wrapper filled with seasoned ground meat, vegetables, or a combination of both. They are pan-fried or steamed until the wrapper is golden and crispy, with a savory filling. Visually, they have a folded or pleated appearance, often served with a dipping sauce on the side.

They are typically served with a spicy dipping sauce and are characterized by their pleated edges and slightly crispy exterior.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is made by folding a thin dough around a mixture of ground meat and vegetables, then pan-frying or steaming until golden brown. They are served with a spicy, tangy dipping sauce. Visually, gyoza appear as slightly crispy, irregularly shaped dumplings, often served in a circular arrangement on a black plate, accompanied by a small bowl of vibrant orange dipping sauce.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, features a thin, crispy wrapper filled with a savory mixture of ground meat (pork and/or shrimp) and vegetables. They are pan-fried until golden-brown and often served with a vibrant, spicy dipping sauce. The dish is visually appealing with its translucent, slightly crispy wrapper and the contrasting bright red sauce.

They are typically served hot, garnished with a light sauce, often soy-based, and are enjoyed as a snack or part of a meal.

The filling is包裹 in a thin, translucent wrapper, and they are often served with a dipping sauce.	<>	Gyoza are dumplings with a savory filling of ground meat, vegetables, and spices. They are pan-fried until crispy on the edges, giving them a golden-brown, slightly charred appearance. The plump, translucent wrappers can be slightly translucent, revealing the rich, savory filling inside.

They are golden-brown, slightly crispy on the outside, with a soft, savory filling inside. They are pan-fried or deep-fried until golden and crispy. They are pan-fried until crispy, creating a slightly charred exterior. They are pan-fried until golden brown and crispy, giving them a crispy exterior and a juicy interior. When served, they are often accompanied by a side of soy sauce for dipping. They are pan-fried or pan-grilled until golden brown, with a slightly crispy exterior and a steaming, moist interior. The filling can vary in texture and flavor, offering a savory bite that contrasts with the chewy wrapper.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is made with ground meat and vegetables, encased in a thin, golden-brown wrapper. They are pan-fried until crispy on the outside and juicy inside, often accompanied by dipping sauces for added flavor.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, is typically made with ground meat or vegetable filling, wrapped in a thin, translucent wrapper made from wheat flour and water. They are pan-fried until golden brown on the outside and juicy on the inside, creating a crispy exterior with a soft, steamed interior. The filling is often seasoned with soy sauce, mirin, and dashi.	<>	Gyoza, a Japanese dumpling, consists of a thin, golden-brown wrapper filled with a mixture of ground meat and vegetables. It's typically pan-fried until crispy and golden, with a soft, steamy filling visible through the translucent wrapper.
